awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Examining Factors that Foster Low-Income Latino Middle School Students' Engineering Design Thinking in Literacy-Infused Technology and Engineering Classrooms
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) proposal responsive to Program Solicitation NSF 15-555. The CAREER program is a National Science Foundation-wide activity that offers the most prestigious awards in support of junior faculty who exemplify the role of teacher-scholars through outstanding research, excellent education and the integration of education and research. The project will investigate how literacy-based instructional strategies, as well as contextual factors, mediate the development of engineering design thinking of low-income Latino middle school students, including English learners, as they attend technology and engineering courses. Engineering design thinking will focus on fundamental aspects of this discipline, such as identifying a problem; considering possible solutions; formulating a plan for the solution; developing, implementing, and testing the plan; evaluating results, redesigning the plan, and testing it again. Literacy-based instructional strategies will include comprehension (summarizing, predicting, inferring, and questioning written text); vocabulary (constructing explicit definitions by making connections to their students' background knowledge); writing-to-learn heuristic (identifying a need, defining a problem, generating solutions, testing, observing results, making claims based on empirical evidence, optimizing, and reflecting on how ideas change); and argumentation (thinking and articulating the relationships between claims and evidence). Technology and Engineering courses are based on the application of existing technology within the field of engineering through the use of basic engineering principles and technical skills, while simultaneously addressing national literacy, science, and engineering standards. These courses are designed to acquaint students with the states' labor markets and the employment opportunities for which they can prepare.

The study will focus on three research questions: (1) How do literacy-based instructional strategies mediate the development of engineering design thinking?; (2) How do features of technology and engineering classroom settings seem to support students' literacy and engineering design?; and (3) How do contextual factors appear to afford or constrain middle school technology and engineering teachers' use of literacy-based instructional strategies? Employing a staggered design-based research and its iterative cycle of design, implementation, and retrospective analysis; the project will work with (a) 10 urban and rural middle schools, (b) 10 teachers who teach mandatory technology and engineering courses, (c) 22 classrooms, and (d) 660 students over the course of 7 trimesters, as they integrate engineering design and literacy. Each classroom will be organized in small groups (pairs of students) representative of English language proficiencies (e.g., English learners at different proficiency levels; non-English learners) to promote cooperative learning, facilitate the implementation of the literacy strategies, and trace evidence of conceptual change in the context of engineering thinking. Data gathering strategies will include classroom observations, video- and audio-taped of pairs working, pre- and post-surveys, and interviews with students and teachers. Data interpretation strategies will include retrospective analysis, microgenetic learning analysis, within-case analysis, cross-case analysis, and constant comparative analysis to identify the features of the technology and engineering classroom settings that support students' engagement with literacy. Case studies will result in contextualized profiles of student learning in particular learning environments, suitable for identifying the consequences attributable to the treatments and describing the mechanisms and conditions under which these relationships occur within the target population. The key outcome of the proposed study will be a literacy-infused engineering design, research-based and field-tested model of instruction for middle school Latino students, potentially adaptable in other similar settings. A four-member advisory board with expertise in engineering, engineering design, and literacy instruction will oversee the work annually and assess completed tasks. An external researcher will be responsible for the formative and summative evaluation of the project.

Major Activities:

For this final no-cost extension, we spent the majority of time in analyzing data and preparing materials for dissemination.

We mentored two graduate students through the process of analyzing data on Technology and Engineering (TE) teachers’ literacy instruction for a manuscript that is under preparation for the Journal of Literacy Research.

We authored an article that was accepted for publication and was published in the Journal of Pre-College Engineering Educational Research. "

We authored and submitted an article that received a “minor revision” decision from the Journal of Engineering Education on middle school students’ problem scoping practices.

We developed and published a website with high-interest trade books for use by engineering teachers. These books have been advertised and used in secondary (middle or high school) TE classes throughout the state of Utah.

Significant Results:

Journal of Engineering Education Manuscript: This analysis indicated that middle school students’ problem scoping continued throughout the duration of the design cycle, and that they were able to develop more comprehensive articulations of problems when their technology and engineering teachers used prototypes and open-ended questions as mediational tools. The full PDF of the methods and results from this analysis has been uploaded under “documents.”

Journal of Pre-College Engineering Education: This analysis highlighted contextual factors that made it easier or more difficult for TE teachers to leverage linguistically diverse students’ funds of knowledge and home languages in the class. The full PDF of the methods and results from this analysis has been uploaded under “documents.”

What opportunities for training and professional development has the project provided?

During the final year, the project provided opportunities for professional development for three current or former graduate students who met bi-weekly with the PI to co-analyze data and prepare articles for publication.

Have the results been disseminated to communities of interest? If so, please provide details.

We submitted results to researchers in engineering and literacy education through the following publications:

Wilson-Lopez, A., Strong, A., & Washburn, H. K. (minor revision). Toward a model of pedagogical tools and contexts that support middle school students in articulating design requirements in engineering. Journal of Engineering Education.

Wilson-Lopez, A., & Acosta-Feliz, J. (2022). Middle school engineering teachers’ enactment of pedagogies rooted in funds of knowledge and translanguaging. Journal of Pre-College Engineering Education Research. Retrieved from: https://docs.lib.purdue.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1356&context=jpeer  

Wilson-Lopez, A., Strong, A., Hartman, C., Davis, L. (in preparation; analysis completed). Shifts in engineering teachers’ literacy pedagogies in the context of disciplinary literacy coaching. Journal of Literacy Research.

[Here you can insert information about what you have done to create and advertise the website.]

 

PARTICIPANTS ORGANIZATIONS

What individuals have worked on the project?

Hartman, Christina: PI

Contributions to the project: Developed the project website and disseminated it to TE teachers through building a classroom library at a local high school, connecting with librarians and volunteers to share the website, sharing the website with 100+ preservice teachers who were about to build their own classroom libraries; analyzed data and co-authored articles for publication.

Amy Wilson-Lopez, PI: Nearest Person Month Worked: 2

Contribution to the project: led bi-weekly meetings with research team and took primary responsibility for authoring manuscripts for publication.

Karen Washburn, Graduate Student: Nearest Person Month Worked: 2

Contribution to the project: Analyzed data and met weekly with PI to discuss emerging findings; co-authored manuscripts for publication.

What is the impact on the development of the principal discipline of the project?

Several disciplines, such as science and history, have decades of publications on how to enact literacy-infused pedagogies and the benefits of doing so. However, engineering education has historically been understudied in this regard. This study contributed to the advancement of knowledge on (a) professional development and contextual supports that enable engineering teachers to infuse language- and literacy-infused pedagogies; (b) pedagogies that support diverse students in developing more multi-faceted articulations of problems (an essential and difficult component of design thinking); and (c) examples of language and literacy-infused engineering pedagogies in practice.

What was the impact on teaching and educational experiences?

While the professional development for engineering teachers occurred in prior years of the study, one purpose of this research was to understand contextual factors and professional learning approaches that supported middle school engineering teachers in enacting language- and literacy-infused pedagogies in different ways. The results from these publications may therefore inform other teaching and educational experiences through advancing knowledge on professional development approaches and teaching approaches in engineering that ultimately support students’ learning.
